data.text: The pride of the height, the clear firmament,
The sun when it appeareth, declaring at his rising
At noon it parcheth the country,
A man blowing a furnace is in works of heat,
Great is the Lord that made it;
He made the moon also to serve in her season
From the moon is the sign of feasts, a light that decreaseth in her perfection.
The month is called after her name, increasing wonderfully in her changing,
The beauty of heaven, the glory of the stars,
At the commandment of the Holy One they will stand in their order,
Look upon the rainbow, and praise him that made it;
It compasseth the heaven about with a glorious circle,
By his commandment he maketh the snow to fall apace,
Through this the treasures are opened:
By his great power he maketh the clouds firm,
At his sight the mountains are shaken,
The noise of the thunder maketh the earth to tremble:
The eye marvelleth at the beauty of the whiteness thereof,
The hoar frost also as salt he poureth on the earth,
When the cold north wind bloweth,
It devoureth the mountains, and burneth the wilderness,
A present remedy of all is a mist coming speedily:
By his counsel he appeaseth the deep,
They that sail on the sea tell of the danger thereof;
For therein be strange and wondrous works,
By him the end of them hath prosperous success,
We may speak much, and yet come short;
How shall we be able to magnify him?
The Lord is terrible and very great,
When you glorify the Lord, exalt him as much as you can;
Who hath seen him, that he might tell us?
There are yet hid greater things than these be,
For the Lord hath made all things;
